awd_titl_txt: A comprehensive computational framework for analysis and optimization of wave energy converters
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Raessi, Mehdi
Proposal Number: 1236462
Institution: University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth
Title: A comprehensive computational framework for analysis and optimization of wave energy converters

Sustainable energy extraction from ocean waves represents an enormous source of renewable energy and promises to contribute towards the energy independence of the United States while addressing rising environmental concerns over fossil fuels. However, the process of bringing a wave energy converter (WEC) design from the lab to commercial deployment is long and costly and is hindered by the complexity of the underlying ﬂow physics.  There are several critical scientiﬁc concerns that are diﬃcult or impossible to study in the lab at early design stages of WECs.  They include assessing the performance of a full scale array and engineering a WEC that is optimized for a speciﬁc deployment site to achieve maximum performance.  Computational methods can provide the ability to address such concerns early on in the development process and are capable of shortening the timeframe and associated costs of the design process.

Currently, almost all computational tools for analysis of WECs are based on linearized hydrodynamic equations in place of the full Navier-Stokes equations. As a result, they are unable to capture non-linear eﬀects, e.g. wave breaking, turbulence, and ﬂuid-structure interactions, that signiﬁcantly impact the performance of WECs. Without capturing these eﬀects, a typical linear model will have a very limited scope in the development process of WECs. Thus, there is an urgent need to bridge the gap between WEC development eﬀorts and computational modeling techniques by introducing a comprehensive computational framework for design and optimization of WECs that includes all important eﬀects.  

This project will utilize a comprehensive computational framework for analysis and optimization of WECs under real-world conditions. The proposed computational tool incorporates non-linear eﬀects and provides site-speciﬁc simulations including (a) a turbulent (both direct numerical simulation, and large eddy simulation), two-phase ﬂow solver driven by wave ﬁelds derived from phase-averaged wave model for realistic and site-speciﬁc inﬂow conditions, (b) a ﬂuid-structure interaction model, and (c) an uncertainty quantiﬁcation model to guide sensitivity analysis and optimization studies of WEC design. To enable rapid turnaround of simulations, the PI will continue eﬀorts in migrating these modules to a heterogeneous CPU/GPU computing environment.  The PI will use the experimental datasets available publicly (Salter?s WEC) and from an industry partner (Resolute Marine Energy) to validate the proposed computational  tool.    The PI will then perform design and optimization studies on, among other devices, a WEC developed at UMass-Dartmouth (UMD) for small-scale, wave-driven generators for remote areas.

The proposed computational tool can accelerate the development and deployment of cost-eﬀective WECs, which can potentially transform renewable energy eﬀorts in the United States. The project will train two graduate and three undergraduate students. The outreach and dissemination plans target a wide spectrum of audience including high school students/teachers, local communities of New Bedford and Fall River, international scientiﬁc communities of marine renewable energy, engineering, and computational sciences, and members of social media.

por.por_cntn:
Ocean waves represent a vast energy resource that has largely remained untapped. To transform renewable ocean wave energy to a major contributor to our energy market, substantial research and development (R&D) effort is still warranted towards making wave energy converter (WEC) devices economically viable and commercially competitive. Computational simulations can significantly help and accelerate the above R&D efforts by complementing and leveraging laboratory and field experiments.

In this project, we developed an advanced computational framework that solves the full 3D flow equations (Navier–Stokes equations) in multi-phase flows and accurately computes the interaction between waves and WEC devices. Because no simplification was made in the hydrodynamic equations, all important effects influencing the fluid–structure interaction are resolved; hence, a wide variety of WEC devices can be simulated under real-world conditions. The above computational tool, which has been extensively tested and validated, introduces several novel numerical techniques that are highly relevant to other engineering and research applications involving multi-phase flows. Examples include numerical techniques to accurately track volumes of three different phases (e.g., liquid, gas, solid) in a 3D domain, and to capture the interaction between a moving solid structure and two-phase (liquid and gas) flow.

To accelerate the simulations a fast pressure solver (multigrid preconditioned pressure Poisson solver) was developed, which significantly reduces the turnaround of large-scale MPI-parallel simulations. Furthermore, using Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) for simulation acceleration, the feasibility of cloud-based high performance computing (HPC) resources for performing parallel multi-phase flow simulations was assessed.

Following extensive testing and validation studies, we performed several 3D simulations on two WEC devices: bottom-hinged pitching cylinder and flap-type WECs. The results of our simulations showed excellent agreement with wave tank experimental results. Additional simulations were performed to examine the performance of each WEC device at full-scale and to investigate the applicability of Froude scaling, which is commonly used for predicting full-scale WEC response from the model experiments.

The results of this project have been presented in six peer-reviewed journal papers and fourteen international conference presentations. The project supported five graduate and undergraduate research assistants, who were trained in wave energy conversion and advanced computational methods, including incompressible multi-phase flow simulations, fluid-solid interaction, parallel and high-performance computing, and cloud-based HPC.

The PI developed a new undergraduate technical elective course in Mechanical Engineering, titled Ocean Wave Energy Conversion, which has been offered every Spring semester since 2014. In addition to covering the fundamentals of wave mechanics and wave energy converters, the results of this research project were presented in the classroom to support the teaching material. Over the past years, 64 Mechanical Engineering seniors and juniors at UMass Dartmouth took the course for credit and evaluated the course very positively.

The project has led to a comprehensive computational tool for simulation of wave energy converters and is poised to make an impact on the field of marine renewable energy. The computational tool can be used to perform analysis and optimization studies on wave energy converters and reduce the experimental costs associated with such studies. Finally, the 3D tool can be readily employed to investigate a wide variety of three-phase flows, where a two-fluid flow interacts with moving solid objects.
